Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of W2 - Multidirectional Offshore Wind-Wave Generation System

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant will enable the University of Maine (UMaine), along with partners Sandia National Laboratories, the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL), and Maine Maritime Academy (MMA), to design, develop and construct a unique multidirectional Wind-Wave generating system, called W2. With a novel rotating open-jet wind tunnel positioned over a 30m long x 9m wide x 5m deep wave basin, W2 will use a programmable directional wave maker to simulate wave and wind environments typical of the Gulf of Maine, Gulf of Mexico and elsewhere. The pivoted wind generator will produce hurricane-speed winds, while allowing variation in wind direction from 0 -180 degrees relative to the wave. The wind environment will replicate wind shear effects, as well as turbine wake effects over water in the ocean, making possible new breakthrough research on ocean-related processes and energy harvesting devices.

W2 will provide a research platform for developing novel offshore wind concepts and software tools to optimize the performance of renewable energy devices and design of offshore and coastal infrastructure. Undergraduate and graduate students will use the facility for their capstone projects, internships and research. The instrumentation will also enhance the research team's participation in the NSF ADVANCE project and other university efforts to increase the participation of underrepresented minority and Native American students in doctoral STEM programs. The equipment will be used for K-12 outreach activities and by other users including the offshore oil and gas industry, ocean energy developers, coastal engineers, and oil spill management companies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant enabled the University of Maine (UMaine), along with partners Sandia National Laboratories, the National Renewable Energy Laboratory and Maine Maritime Academy, to design, develop and construct a unique Wind-Wave generating system, called W2.  The system consisted of a 32-fan open-jet wind tunnel positioned over a 30m long x 9m wide x 4.5m deep basin. A multi-directional wave generating system and an effective beach system were deployed on opposite ends of the basin.  The wind wave generation system was calibrated and benchmarked over the final year of the project. Specifically, benchmark experiments on a floating moored platform and a floating offshore wind turbine were conducted and compared with data obtained from prior experiments at reputable Canadian and Dutch facilities.

The NSF MRI forms an integral part of the Alfond W2 Ocean Engineering laboratory at the University of Maine. The facility was already used to support the US DOE Wave Energy Prize Competition. The laboratory has attracted significant interest from industries that deal with new technologies for energy production from the ocean, as well as those that deal with testing and validating existing technologies for offshore oil and gas production. With its unique wind and wave machines, moving floor and a soon to be installed tow carriage system, the Alfond W2 laboratory has created significant interest in renewable energy, nearshore oceanography, coastal engineering and aquaculture.

The NSF project has directly supported five engineers/ scientists/graduate students, who are from diverse ethnic groups. An engineer and a graduate student who worked on the NSF project are now employed as staff of the Alfond W2 ocean engineering laboratory.

The fundamental desire to develop the Wind Wave facility is to provide a laboratory for advanced testing of marine energy devices and platforms. Testing will provide offshore platforms with higher level of design confidence and improved safety. Such steps are necessary to minimize risks of accidents and reduce environmental and community impact. Improved design of renewable energy systems like offshore wind systems will improve the technology’s financial viability and enable bringing such systems into mainstream. Several catastrophic events, including intense storms, are attributed to global warming including heating up of the upper layers of the ocean. Every step taken by technology developers, industries and communities to reduce greenhouse gas emissions will contribute to improving the living conditions of the entire globe.
